Oooh boy, this is an odd one...

When I came along to see this game on sale, I thought what would await me was a cheesy, but pretty RPG with puzzles to solve and battles to win, much like the advertised likeness to Zelda and Psychonauts. What greeted me instead was an almost childish flower-picking simulator with the most gorgeous artstyle I ever saw.

And I didn't mind.

I bought this game, like some other people, because of the screenshots, and the promise of reliving some of the charm of the games of my childhood. I'm not normally a person who cares much for graphical fidelity in games so long as the gameplay is fun, however in this case? Quite the opposite. Something about the graphics style just makes me innately happy whenever I look at it. It puts my mind to rest for a while, which as a person with depression and anxiety attacks is a bloody godsend. The entire game is very colorful, vivid and nicely stylized, with very fluent animation, adorable little details and an overall just... happy feeling to it. It's easily one of the best-looking games I've played in my life, and it does so not through polygon count, but clever, passionate stylization. Don't get me wrong, though, the models are still pretty high quality.

With the graphics out of the way, though, let's address gameplay. This is where I initially felt cheated by the storepage claiming such close resemblance to the Zelda and Psychonauts games. I imagined adventuring, clever puzzles and dangerous trials. What I got was Flower Picking - Collector's Edition"

reviewText:
Lili is a short, casual, visually exceptional 3D adventure game that's heavy on atmosphere and charm but light on story and variety.

Pros:
- Visuals are gorgeous. It does not look at all like a mobile port and has some of the best visuals I've come across in an indie game.
- Fully 3D world that you can wander around in at your own pace.
- Nice atmosphere. The island is populated with lots of whimsical characters and the game oozes charm.
- Non-violent, suitable for children old enough to have a fair degree of reading comprehension but also accessible for adults. (I realize this may be a con for some who are looking for a more meaty sort of game)
- Unique. It's a bit different than pretty much everything else out there.

Cons:
- Not the greatest value considering the price to length ratio. I like short games but $20 for a few hours play feels a bit steep to me.
- Game play is rather repetitive. You do the same few things for the entire game, namely collect items and play the same sort of quicktime mini game in lieu of actual battles. This is somewhat forgivable given the very short length of the game however.
- The 4 zones are small and there's not much interaction with the environment.
- Story is rather thin and there is no intro; you just get plopped in.
- Only partial controller support. The developer states full controller support is in the works. At present you can run around the world, collect items, check your map and talk to npcs with the controller but going into menus and playing the mini game battles requires keyboard and mouse.
- Full controller support has now been added. Sort of. They basically did a virtual mouse pointer that the left analog stick controls but it feels very shoehorned in as an afterthought rather than controls designed around a controller. Lili: Child of Geos is a collect-a-thon that just exudes charm. I've never had such a fun time collecting flowers and strange garbage from chests in a long time. Just don't go into this expecting Zelda-like combat or something similar to Banjo-Kazooie. You're simply plopped onto a charming little island that can simply be described as something out of a dream.

Here's a Quick Look video to see what the game is like, since it's hard to describe with words. But if that's not your thing, then just read my quick and concise review below.

http://youtu.be/E2t3cuWZZs8

I'll begin by describing the basic mechanics of this game. You play as girl named Lili who is an explorer, and she comes to the island to collect flowers for a report she's doing. You get these special flowers by finding spirits--basically human logs with masks--straddling onto their backs, and plucking white flowers that pop up on their backs until you reach the red one that you need. A fun little mini-game that's somewhat challenging if you're going for the best rank. The other things you'll be doing to progress the story are exploring the village, talking to the inhabitants, and generally exploring for neat things to collect.

But what makes this game so charming? The game's art style is truly breathtaking. It makes the game's main feature of exploring even more enjoyable when there's so many interesting things to see. I even enjoy scaring away birds and laughing at the rainbow turds they leave behind occasionally. Even talking to the local inhabitants is a joy. They have no qualms making fun of themselves and enjoy pointing it out to you. I found it very refreshing to actually WANT to talk to every NPC and find out what their story was. Not many games can pull something like that off.

Other neat features the game has is the ability to chose how you want to upgrade yourself. You can choose to upgrade your speed, grip, or stealth however you wish to suit the playstyle you enjoy. You can also purchase upgrades in a wide range without much restriction. Personally I chose to get a map and key early rather than items to help me fight spirits since I just like exploring more. But if none of that is your thing, you can also just unlock different color swaps for Lili to make her look even more adorable. The choice is yours.

However, this game does come with a few negative.
*I found a game-breaking bug early on. I had collected all of the flowers on the map before hitting up the trainer, who wanted me to collect 5 FRESH flowers. And since none were left, I couldn't progress the game. (I've found out another work-around for this is just quiting and loading your save again. However, I still think it's an issue if you have to do such a strange thing just to continue the game, so I'll leave this as a negative.)
*Because of the above, I also found out that there isn't multiple save slots. I had to delete my old game if I wanted to start fresh.
*There isn't an voice acting besides the occasional Hi" and what not. While it's not really a big deal for me

This game inspires such mixed feelings in me.

It's rather attractive and at times really humorous. There's a conscious, snarky kind of wit to it at times that I think is one of the major strengths in this game. It's very much aware of the type of game it is trying to be and I've always had a fondness for games that break the fourth wall so there's definitely no complaints from me about that. I love it. Give me more of it.

Lili? I actually really liked her as a main character. One of the main reasons I kept playing was to see what kind of sarcastic, funny little thing would come out of her mouth. The rest of the characters as well (and there are a lot of them that you can talk to) were great fun and I loved going around and talking to all of them. This is definitely a game that made me want to explore.

That being said...the actual premise of the game was pretty grating and got boring way too fast. Almost the entirety of the plot is made up of what is best described as a mini-game where you pick flowers off of villain characters. It's something that I can see working well on an iPhone game but as a computer game it is a little obnoxious. Even the side quests really amount to nothing more than open up a chest that is easily found and return the item in it to the person who mentioned it offhand.

The in-game menu can use some work too. Your quests/side-quests are listed in the most basic manner without really giving you information about it. And honestly, it's just...clunky and awkward looking.

You can tell a lot of love went into this game and I can see it easily becoming something wonderful but at the moment it's just in an awkward place between iPhone game and computer game and it suffers greatly for it. I got it on sale and I'm glad I did. I wasn't really spend near $20 on it in the state it is now.

reviewText:
I thought long and hard about whether to give this game a thumbs up or thumbs down, and it was a very tough decision but in the end I just couldn't ignore the feeling of emptiness that I got from this game.

TL;DR:
Go on youtube and watch a video of this game actually being played before you buy it. If you still think you want it, go ahead, but don't say you weren't warned.

The graphics are beautiful, the world is beautiful, the character and object designs are really nice, and there's even a hint of a decent plot in there. So where did it go wrong?

When it comes down to it, this 'game' is pretty much a flower-picking simulator. You can have as many textures, shaders and polygons as you like but when your core gameplay consists of picking flowers off the backs of tree sprites, you have a problem. Had this been a 3D visual novel or a point and click I'd probably be able to give it a straight thumbs up, but I just cannot get over that fact that this game's core 'gameplay' element is flower picking. People compare this to Zelda, but it's nothing like Zelda, there's exploration but there's no real puzzle element to it, no tools or weapons - just free roaming, talking and flower picking.

I get the impression that this 'game' was made by a 3D modeller to show off their work rather than someone who makes video games. This is one of the massive downsides of modern game making tools, anyone with next to no experience in making games can create a game, but because they don't have experience it falls very far from the 'masterpiece' they are dreaming of. It's like a paint brush, in the hand of an artist it creates masterpieces, in the hand of a child it makes a mess. This is almost the opposite of that - give a 3D artist the tools to make a game and they create a beautiful work in which not much happens. This game proves definitively that games should be and are much more than just good graphics.

I can't bear too much of a grudge because I got it on sale for about £3, but I feel like this 'game' is something designed to sit down and gaze at lovingly rather than actually be played. Whoever did the art for this game is definately a true artist, even better than the artists for lots of popular, well selling titles. But whoever came up with the gameplay should either spend a long time evaluating what they think games are about or just not be allowed to manage gameplay at all.

All in all it's pretty tragic really, because this game could have been a real masterpiece. Instead it just leaves me with a very empty feeling, somewhere between admiration and regret, like a beautiful rose being picked before it could bloom or a promising young life cut short thanks to a tragic accident.

Wow, the graphics for this game are just adorable. Colorful, cute, plenty of detail in the environments and (mostly) sharp textures.

But gameplay wise you can tell it was designed with mobiles in mind, because there's a mini-game where you have to use the mouse to pluck flowers and the gameplay and story are rather shallow.
The player has to find red flowers by chasing spirits and solve mini-quests ('quests' would be too big of a word, since they usually take a couple of minutes to complete), among other things (like plucking white flowers and opening treasure chests). That's all there is to it really. There isn't much to do, except for a couple of small sidequests.

You can also level up the character in several ways, but these character upgrades are mostly useless because I didn't seem to experience much of an improvement. Experienced gamers in general won't find the gameplay difficult anyway. There's no health bar, you can't die. The only thing that can happen is that you get thrown off the back of a spirit and even then you can try again without any problems. And there are also potions that you can use to speed up your character, make her invisible or that allow you to throw a bomb in order to stun enemies.

Lili Child Of Geos also isn't a long game. I was able to complete it in 2-3 hours. Which was more than enough because the gameplay becomes very repetitive after these couple of hours.

I still think the game is worth the money, if only for the beautiful graphics and for the first few areas. And who knows, maybe they can flesh things out for a possible sequel, make things a bit more interesting ? I'd like to see one, in any case.

reviewText:
Oh, Lili, where have you been all my life? It's hard to argue with anyone that might label this as a port of a casual, mobile, kid's game; you'll play as a young woman on a field trip wandering around an island, picking flowers, making friends and not really being challenged all that much. But while all that may be true, to be so reductive is to a do a great disservice to an amazing hidden gem of a game.

The most obvious strength of Lili: Child of Geos is its visuals, as there's a glowing radiance emitting from every individual pore of the world along with everything that populates it. But what's less obvious is the writing that backs it up. I feel like the dialogue in a lot of games is there merely to facilitate moving the player to the next objective or set piece, and I guess that's fair enough since actual game play is typically going to be the feature that gets top billing while the story is little more than connective tissue to form vague context for your actions. However, I think people sometimes forget gaming is an entertainment medium, and there's lots of other ways to entertain besides pure play, a fact this game thankfully does remember and arguably makes its greatest triumph.

The story is a strange mix of being playfully throw-away and surprisingly thoughtful and philosophical. Lili travels to the island of Geos in search of its unique floral life as part of a final school exam, but once there finds it is inhabited by Spirits and their workforce of slave Constructs. These large, wooden homunculi must tolerate the bullying whims of their masters lest they cease to exist upon failure to serve their purpose. I probably make it sound much heavier than it really is, but it does at least dabble with notions of free will and life choices and prioritising the things that are really important to us, which are bigger issues than most titles will ever dare to approach. As it transpires, these Spirits have the most exotic flowers, which also gives them their power over the Constructs, setting the scene for several hours of roaming Geos searching for Constructs to help and Spirits to deflower.

Geos is made up for four medium sized districts that are unlocked sequentially as you rid each one of its Spirits. The game and its world may not be huge, but that just allows them to focus on populating it with beauty as every inch of the environments are lovingly crafted with a wondrous level of detail. In many games you'll find yourself wandering into some stranger's house and find the entirety of their personal dwelling is made up of a table and a few chairs, or maybe a bunk bed and a fireplace if they're lucky, that sort of thing. I love how every single house in this game looks properly lived-in, with bedrooms, kitchens and even bathrooms, which really sells the illusion that this is a real world being inhabited by real people... or wooden slaves and freaky tree spirit things, in this case. I really wish more games would take the same effort to make the peripheries of the world just as interesting as its core like this one does.

Unfortunately, when it comes to game play, that's where I'd probably have to admit the game is at its weakest. You'll spend the majority of your time here either picking flowers, smashing vases, looting chests, talking to people or ambushing Spirits, with the amount of time you spend on each of these things pretty much depending on the type of player you are and what you decide to make your goals for this game. There's no combat as such, and you can't die, the only real challenge being trying to jump on the backs of the game's 50 Spirits and playing rodeo with them as you pluck their flowers off. Otherwise it's all a very leisurely affair, the only other complication being upgrades to help make your plucking experience a little easier.

So, yes, it's kinda short, it's arguably shallow in some areas, and it isn't massively challenging, but there really is so much warmth and charm and personality exuding from every part of this game that I feel like it more than makes up for any other shortcomings. Lili herself in particular is the very embodiment of this as she's an incredibly lovable foil to the rest of the cast and a perfect example of a well-balanced female lead that's entirely capable in her own right rather than lazy developers falling back on sexuality to sell a character. I think there's still great depths of enjoyment to be drawn from Geos, and especially from Lili herself, and I can't wait to join her again on her next adventure.

While I have to praise the graphic quality, which is gorgeous and cute, there are some very notable concerns over Lili game as a whole.

Taking its former form as mobile games, Lili is notably short, prolly six hours or so. Ten if you intend to complete everything. No no, it's not a problem and sometimes I appreciate a short game. Then again, because there's a template of mobile game, you can immediately notice it. The gameplay revolves around fighting enemies with tap and drag combination mechanic - a pretty much suitable one for mobile. Not to mention the simplicity of the puzzles for game progression. Well, after all, this is aimed for casual game, so if you want more challenge forget it.

Moreso, there is no voice acting and so it's kinda annoying to see 'Hi' 'Hello' 'Hmpphh' being used all over the maps. This is for me a major negative score for Lili.

Story is... err... very forgettable.

The Developer took care and added gamepad support. Most of the times I'd use controller whenever a game supports it, but for Lili I'd rather go with KB/M - much quicker and precise that way. The control schema I used was WASD/MMORPG-like, and it was smooth enough for the whole time I spent here.

Still, for a buck I spent on it, I wouldn't complain. I got my money's worth (after all I've beaten the game, that's an... achievement by itself), and I'm sure you would also if you can find a bargain elsewhere. Not worth full price, however, because of reasons I wrote above.

Final verdict 6.5/10 - sweet game to take a break from your serious gaming session.

reviewText:
There is much to love here, and only a few things holding it back from complete greatness.
Lili: Child of Geos is an adventure game where you go around a gorgeous island collecting flowers for a school report.
The island is populated by Spirits and the wooden Constructs they've created to be their servants, you'll likely be doing something about that balance along the way since Spirits have the rarest flowers growing on their backs...

Yep, not a normal game this. There's no real combat, in lieu of that there's a minigame where you run after spirits (or take them by surprise using enviromental cover / invisibility potions), climb on their back and try to grab their flowers.
In defense the Spirit grows thorns and bombs. You have to press the buttons that are attached the flowers (more flowers) and to the bombs (less explosions in the face) whilst avoiding the buttons attached to thorns (because they're thorns).

It's not the deepest minigame ever, and you'll be playing it a lot, but there's a charm to it too, as there is to the entirety of the game.
There are 4 gorgeous areas in the game, a beachside town, a night-time town, a forest and... another town. They are decently sized, and filled with a variety of constructs to befriend and help out with little quests (~3-4 per area).
Among the way you'll be collecting flowers that grow around the area, smash pots to find gold and items useful for the mini-game, use keys (also found in jars or traded for flowers) to explore sealed off areas and find treasure chests containing a sizeable amount of gold and a Lore Item (collectible with a bit of backstory / reference).
That all sounds great, so what's the catch? The game is short, and you'll be doing just the things written above. An area can be cleared in ~20-40 minutes, clocking in the total game length at roughly 2 hours.
Other than that there are some technical hiccups, mostly related to achievements not triggering but I also got stuck a few times where the objective didn't tell me the correct next thing to do. Some of the older reviews actually mentioned problems so severe they had to restart to continue, this has since been patched out but it's still not the most flawless piece of code.
It was done by a team of five people though.

So, to summarize:
Pro:
Gorgeous world and presentation
Great protagonist
Great secondary characters, both 'good' and 'evil'
A plot that keeps you entertained
Cons:
Short, like really short
Technical hiccups
Somewhat monotonous
All in all I'm super happy I picked up this game, and I look forward to what the developers will come out with next.

Mara.

A very fun casual game, though a little short.

Lili’s gameplay is similar to RPGs at core: you explore the area for treasures, talk to NPCs and fight enemies. In Lili’s case, though, “fighting” is replaced with a minigame where you ride hectically running spirits and pull flowers from their backs (it makes sense in the context ^_^; ), which requires some precise clicking but not hard overall.

In regard of game’s length, completing the game will likely take you some 5 - 7 hours, depending on how through you are with exploring everything and completing achievements.

The Island of Geos is a small place, with only 4 areas to explore. However, what little of game world there is, is thoroughly detailed: every place is unique and each of 4 areas, despite being a part of the same island, has very distinct feel to it. It is complimented by beautiful graphics, which makes exploration of the game world truly enjoyable.

If you are looking for a simple lovely game to relax with, there is a good chance that Lili is just what you need. However if you are looking for a more lengthy or challenging game, Lili probably isn’t for you.

reviewText: Adorable and relatively short adventure game with easy gameplay. You play as the girl Lili who visits the island of Geos to find flowers she needs for a school report. The world  is not very big and it's divided into four areas that unlock as you complete quests. Most of the game is collecting flowers, breaking vases to pick up coins and entering people's houses to find lore items. There is no combat, instead you engage in mini games in which you defeat enemies by plucking flowers off of their backs. (In other words, there's no violence, but there's some vandalism and tresspassing. :D) There are a bunch of NPCs you can talk to, but the game doesn't have voice acting so expect to do some reading. It's worth it, though; although it can easily be categorized as a casual game, it is surprisingly well written and quite funny. Pick this up if you want something relaxing to play or if you need something non-violent and fun for your kids to play.

Lili: Child of Geos is a wonderful casual adventure game. You follow Lili on her quest to free the citizens of Geos from the Spirits by gathering items and collectibles. There's really no point in the game than to immerse yourself with the wonderful cartoon fantasy world while discovering hidden items and collecting flowers - white ones which you can get anywhere and red ones which you need to fight some spirits to get it.

I really enjoyed this game despite of the lack of gameplay and the linear story line. What makes this game so much fun is the great art style and the graphics, this runs smoothly on my 3 yr old gpu, and I can appreciate that.  There are collectable items in the game like hats, pets, and masks. It's a nice addition, but the dresses are just a change in color. It would've nice to see something different.

The music is perfect for a game like this but sometimes it gets a little annoying, I would have liked it to be a little subtle while im exploring and want to hear more of those ambient sounds.

I can highly recommend this to someone bored of the usual games and just want to chill out and enjoy the fantasy world. But if your an average gamer who wants more gameplay and some serious satisfaction out of a game, this isn't for you. I'd say it's great for a collectible, but honestly not worth the price, since the game is too short and replay value is very low.

Graphics: 7 - I like the graphics of the game and the the world of Geos is beautiful.

Gameplay: 4 - There isn't really anything to do here aside from collecting flowers to proceed with quests and maybe collecting  masks and hats.

Music: 7 - The music is above average and will keep you feeling like you are in a cartoon fantasy world, but it gets repetitive. I woud've enjoyed more if I was hearing a more soothing music and more ambient sounds.

Replayability: 3 - The game doesn't offer anything more after you've beaten it once, maybe just to pick up more flowers and vases for achievements, or maybe get those missable hats or masks.

Overall Impression: 7 - I still give it a 7 despite of all the negatives, there is a certain charm to this game the you can only experience once you start adventuring with Lili=)

reviewText:
Presentation
Lili: Child of Geos tells the story of a young botanist, Lili, set on a quest to the supposedly uninhabited island of Geos as part of a school research project, but as the stories never tell the whole truth until you live them, you will soon find out that the island is actually inhabited by creatures called the Spirits and their creations meant to serve them, the Constructs. It won't be long before your arrival will alert the Spirits as your presence starts to influence the lives of the Constructs and make them question their existence as servants, so you will soon be caught up in the affairs of Geos’ locals. As much of a premise for a serious plot there is, the game chooses tell its story in a satirical way, adding jokes and references to other games every now and then, some which fail to deliver, making the entire story feel irrelevant after you realize most quests are there to fill in the space without an actual outcome in the storyline. As a game that focuses on exploration and the landscape it creates with it, it was disappointing to see how limited that exploration really is; it was exciting to find new items, meet new Constructs and see where else their quests will take me, but after a few minutes you will soon realize that there are only around eight additional sidequests, most which take no longer than ten minutes to complete and as for everything you see in the distance, you will never actually get there.
Rating: 6

Gameplay
As for how the game plays, well it certainly is different from anything you have experienced before, as your main objective is to defeat Spirits by jumping onto their back and picking the flowers that spurt from their heads. This is where the game shows its true nature, as it was originally made for tablets and picking flowers by dragging them with your finger across the screen feels natural and easy, but doing the same thing with a mouse can be a little bit tricky. Using a controller makes the whole thing a little bit easier as you can select the flower you want to pull using the action button, but at the same time it creates another problem, as you can only select from a range of four flowers, mapped to their respective action button, so later on in the game when you'll have to deal with up to eight different flowers, weeds and bombs at the same time, the controller will prove to be more of a burden than a helpful tool. Outside the battle the game works much better, using the keyboard and mouse or the controller to move around, collect flowers, look around for treasures and meet Geos' finest, but then again for an open world experience, there is a really small number of things that you can do outside the main story, which isn't that long either and the first glance at Geos will soon be shattered by exploration limits and the lack of new things to keep you going for longer or distract you from your main objective.
Rating: 5

Graphics
Looking back at the iOS version of the game, it's clear that the visual upgrade worked out for the best and Lili: Child of Geos looks amazing on PC, but the real beauty when playing the game comes from the art style itself, taking you somewhere between what a gnome village would look like and combining it with a good Pixar movie. The landscapes are simply amazing and as for the characters, even if the Spirits look the same except for their masks, the Constructs each have a unique touch to help you recognize them whenever you see them around Geos. The bad part in all this is that you never get to explore everything that you actually see ahead of you and the five different locations of the island can be completed within minutes as there is nothing else to do besides the main objective and a few chests scattered around.
Rating: 8

Audio
The soundtrack complements the visual art style, probably not in the best way possible but its better with it there playing the background as you move on than without it. The worst part on the audio side is the absence of voice acting, which is understandable since most mobile titles lack such things, but as a PC port it's hard not to complain about how great the dialogue could've been voiced by the right actors, and on the same note it could've made some of those lame jokes funny just by using the right voice. The sound effects are okay, but since there is a limited number of items and objects that interact with the environment and your character, it will soon feel like a repetitive and monotone experience.
Rating: 6

Extras
It takes around four hours to finish Lili: Child of Geos, which isn't nearly enough to justify a 20€ price tag, and aside from that and a few achievements that you'll miss on your first playthrough there really is nothing else to keep you around, no matter how beautiful the island of Geos is.
Rating: 4.5

Verdict
Judging by the first look, Lili: Child of Geos is beautiful and unique, but in this case the first look is deceiving, as the game won't last more than a few hours and as for the time in which it actually is entertaining, that's probably less than 30 minutes, but if that time is enough for you and you're just looking for a great view, Lili: Child of Geos delivers flawlessly on that side.
Rating Overall: 5.9

reviewText:
The official description compares this game to Psychonauts, which is fair.  Both games have similar styles in humor (everyone, from Constructs to Spirits to Ominous Fish, has something silly to say to/about you) and design, so if you enjoyed Psychonauts for that aspect (like I did), then you'll enjoy Lili.

The gameplay is also fun.  It's an rpg-esque exploration game, interspersed with an interesting little mini game involving ripping flowers out of the backs of malevolent spirits (never thought I'd say that before).  The scenery is gorgeous, definitely encouraging exploration just by being too darn beautiful to want to leave.  And the minigame was kind of addicting; I wanted to keep playing it and beating each of my high scores, yes, but I also wanted to keep playing it because it was fun.

My only gripe is that the game felt too short.  A couple more quarters to explore (and maybe a few more outfits to collect) would have scratched that itch.  But hey, maybe in the sequel, right?  ;-)

I've barely put in an hour with the Steam version of this game but I already recommend it. I played Lili as soon as it came out for iOS and in my review of the game then I gave it high marks. I give them again this time around.

The best part of Lili for me is that it is full of humor and I actually had a very powerful emotional response to part of the story. It's really that good. But let me pause to point out the one flaw I see in the game.

Unfortunately, punctuation is sloppy and visually stands out against such a flawless graphical backdrop. Admittedly, I'm a stickler for quality writing with careful, consistent use of punctuation and spelling as much as an engaging text. Sadly, this is seemingly the only unpolished bit of Lili. Also, while I appreciate the quirky descriptions and tongue-in-cheek collectibles, there is unexpected semi-questionable content for astute readers.

That being said, I love the feel of this game so get ready for more gushing. The graphics are stunning with beautiful art direction and an immersive environment. This is even truer in the Steam version. It's funny that it looks as I remember it but then when I checked screenshots from my iPhone playthrough, I realized what time and effort really went into this port. The graphics are redone and gorgeous on the big screen!

Lili is a great hero and it's nice to see a nonsexualized female lead. She can be taken seriously and is genuinely likeable. She is also fun to control both on iOS and Steam. I like the control options and found the use of the mouse to give a bit of precision to the main battle" mechanic of the game. I use quotes because there really are no fights other than plucking plants from the backs of spirits and this unique twist is actually very engaging and serves as both a sort of mini game as well as a well tuned challenge in progression.

Finally

reviewText: This is a neat little game. It's very... casual. That certainly is not a bad thing. It's relaxing, easy on the eyes and fun to progress through. The majority of the game consists of walking between four areas, clicking a button next to flowers to harvest them, clicking the same button to kick vases, and occasionally clicking the same button yet again to engage in a minigame where you pull flowers off of spirits. Simple but fun. Where the game really shines though, is in its surprisingly engaging story and characters. This game has some really dark undertones and explores some touchy subjects. Talk to everyone and don't skip the dialogue. I don't really have any major issues with this game. Mostly just insignificant nitpicks, like progression, which requires you to collect red flowers through NPC side quests or through battles with spirits, which isn't a problem in itself, it's just that you don't need a lot to move forward and once you get a couple, you can skip about half the content in the game or do it anyway which essentially accomplishes nothing. It's good that they give a choice of how you can play the game but there's no sense of accomplishment for completing 100% of the game. I don't even think the game keeps track of how many red flowers you get in total. Regardless, I still recommend this game. Twenty dollars does seem a bit pricey but I got a good six hours on my main playthrough and I'll probably return to this game at some point so I'm satisfied.\n\nEdit 8/5/15 : Seems the price dropped to ten dollars. It's definitely worth it now if you don't have it yet.

reviewText:
Lili is a decent a reasonably creative collectathon that I can't imagine getting more than 6 hours out of. It's worth picking up on sale, but not for the full price of $20.

Pros:
- Looks great, especially considering it started on mobile. A lot of that probably comes down to the fact that most levels are cleverly designed to avoid needing to draw more than 20 feet in any direction, but the game does run on Unreal.
- Usually clever writing. Not perfect by any means, but it's generally entertaining.
- Strong world design. The descriptions comparison to Tim Schafer's work is pretty accurate in the world and character design.
- The main mini-game is fun. It involves trying to pick flowers off the head of a spirit as it runs around and sprouts bombs and thorns to make you miss. It's reasonably challenging to win the later rounds with a perfect rating, but you're going to breeze through it if just passing is enough for you. Mileage will vary heavily here.
- Lots of hats. Every spirit (52) and most quests (something like 12?) will give you a hat. There are also at least two pets to find, but the costume changes are limited to palette swaps, unfortunately.

Cons:
- Very limited graphics options. You get a few presets with no descriptions of what any of them actually do. I don't think many people are going to have trouble running the game, but Highest turns on an incredible level of depth of field. I'd have liked to be able to turn that off.
- Short. I finished it in 3 hours. That was enough to defeat all 52 spirits (most with 3/3 stars), complete nearly all of the quests, and find around 60-70% of the collectibles.
- Controls are a bit wonky. Particularly the camera.

reviewText:
Short version: 83%A beautiful and violence-free exploration game, which may have carried some of the repetitive tasks too far, but the unique setting, characters, and the seldom-seen game mechanics really make up for it.

Long version:Lili: Child of Geos is hard to categorise. It’s not an RPG, adventure game or a walking simulator… It’s more of an exploration game with heavy emphasis on item collecting (hence why people call it a flower picking simulator). With some adventure elements in the mix, including “fights”, which are actually simple minigames.

Don’t let the simple gameplay fool you though. Lili is an engaging game about exploring the world of friendly wood constructs and helping them out with their requests. (This usually involves gathering some items or “fighting” an enemy.) It’s not a community simulator like the Animal Crossing series, but has some similarities, including the same non-violent, relaxing charm.

Technically it was ported from iOS, but the only thing that may give it away is the very simple control scheme; the developer practically remade the whole game for PC, which includes astonishing, yet not intrusive visuals– all presented by the Unreal 3 engine– and brand new game elements. It is a version made with love (which sadly doesn’t extend to provide support for technical issues), and if you start playing it, you will feel that love too.

reviewText:
Lili: Child of Geos is an adventure game that reminds me of the newer Zelda games.  You go on quests, break pots to get loot, challenge enemies, unlock doors and the character talk in text not voice.  Lili is a less violent version of Zelda because you can't die and the enemies are defeated and not killed.  Instead of swinging a sword you pick flowers off their head.  It sounds like a cheezy game but I had fun playing it and it takes some effort to get through the game.  The graphics are really good and the gameplay is easy.  This game is no match for Zelda but it's a fun adventure none the less.  Great for all ages.  I would like to note that considering this game was originally a mobile app game I'm impressed how well it's made.

Pros
Simple gameplay
Graphics
Clean language
Not very long (complete around 5-7 hrs).  If this was a Zelda game that would be bad but for this game it's good.

Cons
Achievements - most are easy to get but there's one you can't get with one playthrough which I find annoying.  To get all 3 training achievements you have to play through a second time.  You can get 2 out of 3 in a single playthrough.  Also, the game wants you to collect 1,000 flowers and breaking pots.  The flowers one takes time but not hard if you constantly collect them.  The breaking pots one seems to take forever because there's fewer of them and never marked on your map.  By the time I finished the game I only broke around 500/1,000...ugh!  If you're serious about achievements that will take up more than 5-7 hrs to complete the game.  The achievement issue doesn't make the game bad, just annoying.

In Lili: Child of Geos; you play an invasive, Lara Croft reject, hippie, feminist lesbian human that trolls the ruins of living wood to deflower teenage spirits for her own personal pleasure.

I have enjoyed the game so far but I can't really recommend it for full price. Though the game is beautiful, runs well and has a cute main character, it's just too short. Be sure to grab it on a discount, though.

reviewText:
Lili: Child of Geos is a beautiful yet very simple game that won't appeal to everybody.

As someone who was looking for a change of pace from the average brown, explosion based gritty shooter, Lili: Child of Geos was an amazing pallet cleanser. A nice simple story set on a beautiful island with some really nice stand out characters and an easy yet enjoyable mechanic made for an enjoyable yet short experience that I would recommend to people looking for something a little different.

As mentioned above, the graphics in this game are superb, every area is crawling with life and every nook and cranny seems to have been paid a lot of attention. The character models as well are all unique and portray an enjoyable visual style that makes them feel much more alive as characters, even despite not being voiced.

The dialogue of the game is light hearted and fun, even going so far as to almost break the fourth wall at times when mentioning some of the games obvious limitations.

Sadly, the game isn't voice acted which feels like a slight let down. I feel it could of been the icing on the cake here but as mentioned the dialogue is interesting enough to read through.

The actual second to second gameplay involves a lot of fetch quest like objectives and the whole game is very easy, you can complete it to 100% in about 4-6 hours but the gameplay isn't the draw here and sometimes the IOS roots of the game can be seen.

Lili: Child of Geos is an experience more than a challenge, a nice vacation from the stressful and grim games that most of us play a lot and I loved it, here is hoping for a sequel!

reviewText:
Lili: Child of Geos is a very peculiar and unique game. It is a game that children and adults (channel your inner child adults!) can play and enjoy.
Graphics: When the graphics are set on 'Fantastic', which is the highest value, the game is gorgeous. The view of the island itself is magnificent and the lighting in-game makes the entire game seem somehow enchanted and magical.
Storyline: The storyline is pretty simplistic and one should not expect a complex and in-depth storyline from this game. The plot itself is that you are Lili, a botanist and student sent to the supposedly 'uninhabited' island of Geos to collect samples of flowers to bring back home for your research project. However, you find that the island is not empty and that there are creatures (constructs and spirits and many others) of a different variety.
Gameplay: As you read in the upper section that Lili is a botanist, you may assume that you will pick flowers throughout the game. Yes, you are correct! You will be picking countless of flowers, breaking vases, talking to goofy individuals, scaring birds, finding items, and fighting spirits (yes, you will pick the flowers off of their backs!). You should not expect a hack-and-slash style or a difficult puzzle from this game.
Humor: This game is hilarious. If you actually take your time (like I did) and talk to everyone and read everything, it turns out that our heroine is a gamer! And there are Zelda and Super Mario references (and many more) throughout the game as well as things and topics that would be considered 'inappropriate' are slightly implied so that if your children are playing it, they will not understand. If you are playing it (an adult), you will laugh your butt off!

Overall, I truly enjoyed this game. No, it is not difficult but it is hilarious. It is a relatively short game (I would say approximately 3-5 hours if you don't take time to look at anything, read anything at all, explore, or do side quests), and the only reason I have 9 hours game-time is because I wanted to receive every single achievement (and I also kept going afk while in-game). This game is a good way to unwind after playing a scary game or having a bad day. The hilarity of this game is what kept me coming back!

Lili: Child of Geos is one of the bizarrest games I ever played: an open-world flower picking simulator with a stroke of the RPG-brush.

You play Lili, who visits an inhabited island to collect flowers for a school project. But she does not pick these flowers from the fields or gardens, she only picks the ones that grow along the streets and on the monsters.

On a more negative side, this game features no voice acting, only textboxes.

So, was Lili: Child of Geos any fun for me? Yes, but not 20€ worth of fun, more like 10€.
Conclusion: If you need a tiny charming open-world game for inbetween with an uhmm innovative fighting mechanic and this game is on sale, then give it a try.

reviewText:
Lili: Child of Geos is a love letter to classic 3D adventure games but overall runs a bit long. You could easily burn through its content in a day but the majority of it sadly gets very repetitive very fast. At $20.00, it's a hard sell I'd argue.

You're dropped onto the island of Geos as Lili, a college student persuing a Vege-Magical degree, and become embroiled in a conflict between the island's ruling Spirits and their servant Constructs. Lili's pursuit is not entirely selfless (at first). She's here to study the flowers that dot the island, which most conveniently grow from the backs of the Spirits, forcing her to spend a majority of the game delicately plucking them from her enemies.

As a central mechanic, the spirit combat is great and well realized. The chase to catch a spirit followed by the aforementioned flower picking is great fun, hampered only by the finicky controls thinking you want to stop and either pick flowers or smash jars when you're in hot pursuit. Lili's origins as a tablet game really show up here, as the plucking mechanic has you selecting a flower and dragging it away from a spirit to collect it.  It is fun perhaps the first handful of times, but given that there are over fifty spirits in the game to fight with little variety aside from the number of obstacles that crop up on a spirit, it does make the game's pacing drag if you are going for 100%.

Geos has a lot of bright and colorful details to its world, and it is fun to just wander around the island and see what's in it as the Constructs go about their business. While not a fully realized world like in Deadly Premonition or Majora's Mask, where the characters all follow a set schedule, Geos nonetheless is a delight to get lost in for a few hours and take in the scenery.

It's also good to see Lili realized as a character; she has no love interest and she has no need of someone to come save her. As a plucky protagonist with ideas for what she wants to do with her life, Lili stands up for herself in a game that, while it has action, is at its core a non-violent experience, barring how you feel about picking flowers off the backs of monsters.

It's not a perfect game and suffers from having too many spirits to fight through, but for a quick delightful romp Lili's journey to Geos is one worth undertaking.

reviewText: So Lili: Child of Geos is a quirky, lite RPG, and action-adventure game. The mechanics are simple and easy to understand for gamers of most ages (granted those gamers can read), and the rest of the game is made to be a family friendly adventure. Combat and violence is replaced with a fun little mini-game (which feels awkward on the mouse at first, but you'll get used to it) where you chase enemy spirits across the island, hop onto their backs, and pluck Spirit Flowers off to weaken them while avoiding the thorns and bomb plants that grow there as well. After defeating a spirit you can earn a score and a rating measured in stars, if you earn 3 stars you'll also get a colored version of that spirits mask (there are also fifty unique spirits to encounter, so that means 50 unique masks to unlock). Outside of that minigame, the rest of the game sees you running or walking around the island of Geos, slowly unlocking new zones to explore freely and to find new spirits to defeat inside. The exploration of these zones remind me a little of The Wind Waker, as the island is bright, colorful, and actually very pretty (especially on the highest settings). Unlike Wind Waker though, there are no dungeons to explore (unfortunately) but there are a lot of fun little puzzles to undertake, quests to do for the wood-construct citizens of Geos, and every time you enter a zone, a whole batch of Spirit Flowers (the same kind that grow on the heads of Spirits) spawns in random places for you to collect. Unfortunately a few bugs appear where flowers will grow inside walls or under bridges or just places you can't reach, and there are the occasional clipping issues that block Lili off from small areas she should be able to access, or temporarily stick her into the environment (only happened once for me, but it took me five minutes of running in a circle to get her free), and the zones themselves really aren't too large. However you will find yourself scouring these zones over and over while hunting for spirits, treasure chests, and flowers and the zones are well designed and so different from each other they surprisingly don't get old after a few hours of playing, and with the flowers you find you can sell them for gold coins (used to buy outfits, upgrades, and powerups for taking on spirits), trade them for keys (one key will open any lock on the island, but is destroyed after each use) so you can loot or explore the various houses and shops on the island, or you can use the flowers to gamble with in a minigame I found quite easy (probably just because I have good eyes and reflexes) to try and earn even more gold coins.\nI bought the game on a whim because it was on sale and looked cute, and surprisingly it is now my favorite game of all time, simply because it is so fun, cute, and happy it always makes me feel good when I play, no matter how poopy I feel before loading it up. I've already finished the game (it is rather short unfortunately, but I've heard you can play it for about 40 hours before collecting every single hat, outfit, lore item, mask, pet, and completing every quest) but I want to keep playing it and try getting the game's other ending and explore the bird poop mechanic a little bit more. Yes, there is a bird poop mechanic where if you run too fast while scaring birds, the poor things will fly away and poop all over Lili, leaving rainbow colored droppings all over the girls face and clothes (this always makes me laugh because she always has a calm smile on her face throughout the game).\nSo would I recommend this game? Yes, however the majority of Hardcore gamers probably wouldn't like the game for much more than the billions of references to Dark Souls, Oregon Trail, Mario, Zelda, Minecraft, Prometheus (yes, the movie), and much more. Children would probably love the colors and characters, but a lot of jokes and dialogue would probably be wasted on them. But if you're a total nerd who wants to play a peaceful game that'll just make you laugh and give you at least 3 to 5 hours of sheer happiness (that's the minimum time to beat the storyline), you'll probably love it as much as I do.

reviewText:
This game surprised me. I well knew that the game was only a simple game, all it was about was picking up flowers (lol?) and quick time events fights. So I was prepared to a mediocre game with a good artistic style.

Well, it's much more than that. The style is in fact very pleasant, I would say very well designed levels. You get 5 different levels in which you can free roam (you can't jump so no platforming sessions). Every level is quite different from the other and very suggestive. Every level also comes with its own background music.

The 'fights' consist in getting close enough to the enemy, and triggering the QTE (with the mouse cursor, or with ABXY buttons of the 360 controller). It is a nice QTE, compared to the average QTE in other games. During the fight you also can choose whether to use or not some powers (flash bombs).

The Character can be upgraded and customized (although the outfits are different almost only in colors). The flower picking is not tedious, comes spontaneous while you walk around enjoying the scenery.

When I saw the achievements....picking up 1000 flowers....I thought it was crazy. But no, in fact in only a few hours I did everything in the game and it really was no hassle. I enjoyed every part of it. It is the exact game I was looking for: it is nice, fun enough, and not complicated at all. It is a perfect game for children, or for grownups that want to relax from all the other FPS and action games, and dedicate themselves to this relaxing game. You don't have to reflect, you don't have to plan anything or else, just sit back and enjoy this little game. 80/100

reviewText:
Although I do recommend this title, I do so for specific reasons. Specifically from a design aspect, I find the mechanics to be a fascinating way to have a non-combat oriented game that still proves to be challenging, interesting, and altogether very different.

The mechanics are pretty simple as far as a concept goes: you are a student botenist, and are collecting rare plants to study for a report, and thus go to an island. However, when you get there, trickster spirits get in your way and steal whatever flowers you have collected. To get them back, you must ride them like an unbroken bronco, plucking them while trying to hang on. All in all, very different, and definitely worth studying, especially if you have any interest in game design. Outside of this main gameplay trope, shall we say, there's a fair amount to explore in this world, with flowers showing up around every corner, plenty of people with well fleshed out personalities to talk with, and an interesting stat system to learn to make future, more difficult spirits more manageable.

Then there are the aesthetics. This game is absolutely gorgeous for the few resources it takes. The textures are well placed and the models are incredible. The animations are so carefully crafted, that it draws you into the magical island you have entered. I haven't found anything that feels out of place, or that jars me from the experience of the game, even with all of the collectable hats you can find for your main character.

Now the story is why I recommend this game with caution. Although it is fairly well written, it definitely is aimed towards a target audience that I am just not a part of. I believe this game to be designed with players younger than me in mind, older children into the preteen age. I feel like most children could get something out of this game, although I'm not completely sure how young too young would be for this particular title. However, being in my early 20s, this story simply doesn't compell me personally.

Now even with the somewhat childish atmosphere and story, I still found myself truly enjoying the game. It's not my favorite game, by a long shot, but for what it is, it does offer some decent entertainment for when I just want to relax and play a game that reminds me of the titles that got me into gaming almost 20 years ago.

reviewText:
Lili: Child of Geos is a game I'd kept my eye on ever since it first appeared on steam. It's colorful and unique art style and character designs interested me enough to put it on my watchlist. Having had the chance to finally give the game a playthrough I can see it both met my expectations and also took them in a different direction. This isn't your typical RPG by a longshot. You won't really be level grinding or anything like that as there really is no battle mechanic. You play as a botanist and your typical task on the island is to pick flowers. The best flowers happen to grow on the backs of creatures known as spirits. Picking them off their backs as they try to shake you off takes the form of a mini-game. I hadn't known going in that the game was a revisioned port of an iOS game, but it by far feels like one. That isn't a bad thing however as this game is beautiful to look at and the 'battles' can get quite challenging when thorny flowers and bombs are thrown into the mix. The game is also quite charming with a very unique art style I greatly enjoyed.

I do have a few issues with the game however, the camera has a bit of a wabble motion to it that is noticeable which can't be turned off in the options. If you easily get motion sick, this may get to you at first as it almost did with me, but as you're moving around it becomes less noticable. The game is also dull in parts and repetitive. Especially at first but once the game gains momentum it becomes far more interesting. The game even has a fairly dark undertone which I enjoyed but doesn't ever drown out it's charming and humerous nature. The writing is a bit odd at times though with occasional typos oddly phrased sentences and punctuation errors that hardly ruin the gameplay. Dialog is easy to read and understand even for children, though item descriptions can use words a bit out of reach for younger players. The game also features an auto-save feature which can get annoying towards the end of the game when you're given two choices. I would have liked to have saved at that point manually to reload later and take the other path instead of having to play through again.

All in all, I enjoyed myself while I was playing and genuinely felt myself drawn into the world this game created. This game isn't for everyone and I wouldn't consider it an RPG as it's closer to a modern day point and click adventure. I'd recommend it to ages 10-15, especially to female audiences or Miyazaki anime fans as it has a similar world feel. It won't be a length sit. I finished the game in 5.5 hours, but it does have a branching path towards the end.

reviewText:
Lili is a sweet and enjoyable little family game, hampered by a lack of polish and a rather threadbare plot.

You play Lili, of course, a young student who arrives on a thought-to-be deserted island in search of flowers.  Once there, you discover that a race of beings called Constructs are working as slaves for vicious little critters called Spirits.  Naturally, you'll battle the Spirits, free the Constructs, do a little soul-searching, and save the day.

The gameplay is charming, but fairly limited.  You'll walk around, talk to people, do fetch quests, and fight Spirits in what are essentially QTE mini-games.  You jump on their backs and pluck all of their flowers out, avoiding thorns and shedding bombs as you go.  Defeated Spirits merely run off in a huff; everything is very non-violent and kid appropriate.  There's also a gambling mini-game that is fun for a few spins.

Sadly, there isn't much story to tie it all together.  It's clear that the evil Mayor will be the Big Bad from the get-go, so not much mystery there.  Lili's only real drama is whether or not to abandon the Constructs to turn in her project on time, and I doubt anyone will be very confounded on which path to choose.  Lili will also exchange letters with her professor that hint at some deeper family trauma at play, but it's only brought up at the very end of the game and nothing much is said of it.  Exploring that a little further might have added some real heart to the game and made it feel a bit more substantial.

Of course, many of the game's shortcomings can be traced to its origins as a smartphone app, with an emphasis on sharp graphics and simplistic gameplay.  Make no mistake, the game is quite beautiful, but the transition from app to Steam product was less than ideal.  The game feels a bit unpolished all over, and the achievements are a total mess - some are bugged, others pop up erroneously, and many are tedious grinds which are completely inessential to clearing the game.  The game was perfectly playable on my end and didn't crash, but the whole thing felt rushed.

And yet, with all that said, I'll give the game a mild thumbs up.  It's nice to see a family appropriate game on Steam, especially with a female protagonist.  It looks great, has pleasant tunes, and the writing can be quite funny in places.  You can tell that the adult writers were slipping in a ton of gags to either amuse themselves or any parents nearby.  It all goes down easy and most people will get a few hours of fun out of it.  That said, I got the game for 85% off - I wouldn't pay anything close to the base price of $20 for it.  Something in the $5 range is more appropriate.
